awd_abstract_narration:
ECCS - 1053729 CAREER: Ambient Thermal Energy Harvesting for Power Production

ABSTRACT

Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to increase energy efficiency and sustainability through ambient thermal energy harvesting.  The approach is focused on the capture and use of energy like solar thermal using small-scale devices. Microfabrication and system design contribute to excellent metrics for real-world implementation.  The system operates on a new thermodynamic working cycle, focused on operation at low temperatures associated with ambient thermal energy collection.  Research results in a new solar thermal collector, advanced heat exchangers, and a novel expander suitable for operation in many applications.

Intellectual Merit
This research focuses on the use of highly available thermal energy sources that are largely unused today.  In addition, the approach represents a novel operating cycle dependant on phase change and resonant operation of the expander.  This is a first for this scale of application and thermal energy source.  Advanced fabrication techniques will result in research progress in areas with little prior work.  Finally, the research is well suited for application to other technologies like advanced thermoelectric generators.

Broader Impacts
This research engages a broad spectrum of underrepresented students and community via K-12 outreach and university student integration.  Underrepresented groups make up a high percentage of students in this outreach.  A new undergraduate energy course furthers outreach and impact.  Research results will be published in leading journals, conferences, and workshops.  These results also provide real-world examples for outreach activities.  This outreach significantly impacts energy education on multiple levels and encourages student involvement in advanced energy research.

por.por_cntn:
The engineering Grand Challenges established by the National Academy of Engineering include many of the greatest engineering challenges facing the 21st century. The availability of low cost, efficient energy is among these and includes the importance of solar energy in particular. “Ambient Thermal Energy Harvesting for Power” has been funded by the NSF for a duration of 6 years and has produced progress aimed directly at this Grand Challenge. In addition, significant contributions to education of students in elementary and higher education has been achieved through this work.

 

Intellectual Merit: 

This project has sponsored new solar research resulting in small solar energy collectors that can be used to harvest energy for electrical supply to remote sensors or other small devices. This means that environmental sensors or security sensors have a means to capture energy and operate from the local surroundings. In general, solar energy use will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and have future positive impacts on energy efficiency.

 

This project has also produced advanced technology incorporated with the solar collectors to increase the amount of energy captured. This has been accomplished through new heat exchangers and boilers. These represent new, low-cost systems very well suited to solar energy capture and future application around the energy enterprise. This has also resulted in new work geared toward NASA applications and energy requirements related to the NASA mission.

 

Broader Impacts:

Throughout the project, there has been a high emphasis placed on increasing the interest and engagement of students in the science and engineering fields. This has been accomplished through direct K-12 outreach as well as new courses integrated into the Louisiana Tech University curriculum. This effort has touched hundreds of students (graduate and undergraduate) at Tech, and local schools around the area. Students across the scientific disciplines have been exposed to new ideas and energy fundamentals. First through unique courses on Grand Challenge energy topics, and second through direct work and input on the core research activities of the project itself.

 

K-12 outreach has included new course material for high school level science classes through Louisiana Tech’s “Tech Step” program. These young minds are the future of science and engineering and the key to addressing many of the daunting challenges that face this planet.
